text: <@U3Y0W91QR|tigran_sarkisian> has joined the channel
<@U3YPKCM6Z|emilyg> has joined the channel

hello, for marshmallow, if I already ask for WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE permission, should I also ask for READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE, from App's permissions page, it seems whether it's Read or Write, it is just an on/off Storage permission and not specified as on/off Read Storage or on/off Write Storage
If i remember correctly READ is implicitly granted along WRITE
I think it is written somwhere in official docs
<@U3YKH6TKM|seelass> has joined the channel
thanks <@U0E72HWTX> :taco:
But please check it cause i'm not completly sure
hmmm I did experiment on device... If I ask for read storage permission, on the activity which checks for write storage permission, it is not asking again
vice-versa
Ok. I found it anyway
If you need to both read and write files, then you need to request only the WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE permission, because it implicitly requires read access as well.
<https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/data/data-storage.html>

attachments.title: Storage Options | Android Developers
attachments.text: Android provides several options for you to save persistent application data. The solution you choose depends on your specific needs, such as whether the data should be private to your application or accessible to other applications (and the user) and…

text: "Beginning with Android 4.4, these permissions are not required if you're reading or writing only files that are private to your app. For more information, see the section below about saving files that are app-private."
what do they mean by app-private ... e.g stored in the folder "com.arviio.arviio.myapp"?
I'm not sure really :stuck_out_tongue:
<@U37BP6E73> I think you're correct.  <http://stackoverflow.com/questions/26579869/how-can-i-let-users-access-the-internal-storage-directory-of-my-app>

attachments.fallback: How can I let users access the internal storage directory of my app?

text: so again upon experimentation, without the write_external_storage permission, camera, audio, and video capture will work (saving in e.g com.arviio.arviio.myapp) buuuut when I try to choose from gallery e.g Downloads dir... it won't work anymore... since I'm accessing a public directory.
:joy: :joy: :joy: so if we have to access public dir, we ask to activate write_external_storage manually for Marshmallow above
and then on the manifest use something like `<uses-permission android:name="android.permission.WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE" android:maxSdkVersion="18" />`
I had to deal with Marshmallow permissions for part of a Big Nerd Ranch book tutorial app.  I'll look through my project files...
<@U0BQ32NP5|irv> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/irv/F3YL0UVUK/AndroidManifest_xml.txt|AndroidManifest.xml>
my test devices were 4.2.2 and 5.1, submitted to manager using 6.0.... didn't work :joy: :joy: :joy: ugggh
ya, you can try experimenting it too :smile: for confirmation, I did uninstall/install the app when experimenting so I'm pretty sure it created the dir without the write to storage on Marsh
It took me a few days to figure out why the app wasn't working properly when I uninstalled it vs. running a new build. :scream:
<@U3Y26C39P|atmohsin> has joined the channel
I single-stepped through a lot of code in the debugger to finally figure it out.
so it's the permission on storage?
I think so.

package com.arviio.arviio.myapp;

import android.Manifest;

import android.content.pm.PackageManager;
